title: Opinion: Astros' non-apology another sign of their unchecked arrogance
text:
USA TODAY

The Houston Astros brain trust seems to have forgotten what every Little Leaguer knows. Same for those in charge at Major League Baseball.

Play fair. Be nice. And when you make a mistake, apologize.

As they prepared for Game 1 of the World Series on Tuesday night, the Astros and MLB were engulfed in a debacle solely of their own creation. Displaying the toxic arrogance that is fast becoming their trademark, the Astros first called a Sports Illustrated reporter a liar for her story on assistant general manager Brandon Taubman taunting female reporters with his praise of a pitcher suspended for beating up the mother of his child, then issuing a non-apology apology that included the infuriating and condescending “if anyone was offended” phrase.

Rather than taking a hard line on a franchise that has made boorishness a core value, MLB issued a statement that both sides-ed the issue and then ran for cover.

Outstanding role models all around. But hey! The World Series is about to start, and all will be forgiven if the Astros win their second title in three years.

At least Houston manager A.J. Hinch was mature enough to say that none of this was acceptable, without any qualifiers.

"It's uncalled for," Hinch said. "No one should ever feel like, when you come into our clubhouse, that you're going to be uncomfortable or disrespected.

"We all need to be better across the board in the industry," Hinch added. "I understand why it’s a question today. I appreciate it. I was disappointed."

Disappointed, infuriated, exhausted -- take your pick of emotions and any one of them is justified. There is so much wrong about what happened in the Astros’ clubhouse Saturday night, as well as the team’s defiant defense of it, and it is inexcusable that that still has to be explained.

SI reported Monday night that Taubman repeatedly shouted “Thank God we got (Roberto) Osuna! I’m so (expletive) glad we got Osuna!” in the direction of three female reporters after Houston beat the New York Yankees to reach the World Series.

Osuna was suspended for 75 games in 2018 for violating MLB’s domestic violence policy. SI reported that one of the journalists Taubman yelled at was wearing a purple bracelet for domestic violence awareness.

The Astros’ first instinct, to lie and smear the SI reporter, failed miserably when others stepped forward to corroborate the account.

“I was there. Saw it. And I should’ve said something sooner,” Hunter Atkins, a reporter for the Houston Chronicle, said said on Twitter. The Chronicle later published a story saying three eyewitnesses, two of whom were its own reporters, had confirmed SI’s account.

Only after widespread criticism, by people inside baseball and out, did Taubman and the Astros make a show of remorse.

And a show it was, with Taubman saying his support of Osuna had been “misinterpreted” for willful ignorance about “a social issue.” Why, he’s a “loving and committed husband and father”! – as if no husband or father has ever been ill-informed about domestic violence or has marginalized women.

“I hope that those who do not know me understand that the Sports Illustrated article does not reflect who I am or my values,” Taubman said in his statement. “I am sorry if anyone was offended by my actions.”

When there’s an “if” in an apology, it’s not an apology. People were offended by Taubman’s actions, and rightly so.

Osuna has been a member of the Astros since late last season, and Taubman decided Saturday night was when he should decree what a swell pickup the closer was? And he just happened to direct it to a group of female reporters?

No. Taubman was letting them know that the lives and safety of women are irrelevant when someone can throw 90-plus mph in the ninth inning.

The statement from Astros chairman Jim Crane wasn’t any more sincere, saying that the team is “committed to using our voice to create awareness and support on the issue of domestic violence.” Given the circumstances, Crane probably ought to have chosen his words better.

As for MLB, it chose to hide behind an “investigation,” saying SI and the Astros have different versions of Saturday night’s events. Given that Taubman has now acknowledged the SI report was correct, MLB might want to take another crack at this.

There is a conversation to be had about Taubman’s behavior and baseball’s continued apathy about domestic violence. But the larger problem right now is that the Astros are operating under their own rules, and they don’t much care what anyone thinks of that.

Earlier this season, a petulant Justin Verlander demanded a reporter he didn’t like be barred from the clubhouse until he was done talking. Rather than patiently explaining the role of the news media and why MLB has deemed it important enough to include in the collective bargaining agreement, the Astros kowtowed to their ace and, without any evidence, disparaged the reporter Verlander found so bothersome.

MLB let the Astros know they were in the wrong. But Taubman’s behavior, and the team’s defiant absolution of it, shows the Astros think they can bully people without consequence. And, so far, they’re right.

Teams are given wide latitude in their operations, and rightly so. But when they traffic in misinformation and misogyny, or create a hostile environment for reporters, it is incumbent upon the league to step in.

If MLB isn't up to it, or doesn't recognize why the Astros' behavior is unacceptable, perhaps they should defer to the experts. I'm sure there are some Little League players out there who would be happy to explain.

Follow USA TODAY Sports columnist Nancy Armour on Twitter @nrarmour.
description: An Astros executive shouted vulgar praise for Roberto Osuna, pitcher banned for domestic abuse, toward female reporters. Then, the team lied about it.
